ThingDef.label: tyrannosaurus rex
ThingDef.description: Long extinct theropods, brought back to life as a part of the Dinosaur Revival Project.\n\nThe king of the tyrants; that's the name the earliest of paleontologists deemed suitable for this gigantic beast. A true carnivore, with hind legs clearly made for running, a massive head balanced by a long, thick tail, the T-Rex was one of the largest theropods of its time. It has been debated extensively if this beast was actually a scavenger rather than a predator, or whether it was covered in feathers or scales, but the DNA samples replicated for the reintroduction of the species to the Rimworlds most definitely turned this beast into a scale-covered hunter, putting an end to the debate forever.

ThingDef.label: yutyrannus
ThingDef.description: Long extinct theropods, brought back to life as a part of the Dinosaur Revival Project.\n\nA genus of the tyrannosaurid dinosaurs, the Yutyrannus is unique in the sense that it has at least three nearly complete fossils recovered during the 20th and early 21st Centuries. The oldest known specimen had an estimated lenght of 9 meters (about 30 ft.). Similar to its other Coelurosaurian cousins (which includes modern birds, by the way), the Yutyrannus sported feathers. In fact, it was the largest species which had direct fossil evidence towards the existence of feathers; the Yutyrannus was mostly covered in what is referred to as filamentous "stage 1" feathers.

ThingDef.label: carnotaurus
ThingDef.description: Long extinct theropods, brought back to life as a part of the Dinosaur Revival Project.\n\nWith a set of menacing teeth and two horns sticking from the top of its head, the Carnotaurus surely was a confusing specimen when first discovered. Literally named "meat-eating bull", the Carnotaurus is a cousin of the famed Tyrannosaurus Rex, although much smaller. Its jaw was capable of quick bites in a rapid succession, but not necessarily as strong as that of its larger cousins. It probably swallowed its prey as a whole due to the unusual flexibility of its jaw, similar to snakes. The true purpose of the horns are not known, but it's speculated that they may have been used to headbutt rival members of the same species (although nobody beats pachycephalosaurus in that department).

ThingDef.label: allosaurus
ThingDef.description: Long extinct theropods, brought back to life as a part of the Dinosaur Revival Project.\n\nBefore the Tyrannosaurids existed, the Allosaurus was the king among predators of its time. Having originally existed during the Late Jurassic period, these beasts probably came in constant contact with the Stegosaurus and Diplodocus. Its skull was large and equipped with dozens of sharp, serrated teeth, capable of tearing through the thick skin of large sauropods. Perhaps it was the Allosaurids which caused the Sauropods to grow so large in size. These relentless predators were quite well distributed, with fossils of its subspecies popping up everywhere from Africa to Asia and the Americas.

ThingDef.label: spinosaurus
ThingDef.description: Long extinct theropods, brought back to life as a part of the Dinosaur Revival Project.\n\nWhat the T-Rex and its cousins were for the Americas, the Spinosaurus was for what is today North Africa. With an elongated crocodilian skull, two arms that have not yet deteriorated into small seemingly useless limbs, and a huge fan-like spinal crest, the Spinosaurus was most certainly built to survive in an acquatic biome. With its name literally meaning "spine lizard", it was theorized for long that the spinal fan-sail was to collect heat from sunlight during times of rest. Other theories suggest that the spines were actually covered in fat rather than being connected via skin, and that the animal actually had a hump-back appearance instead of adorning a decorative dorsal-sail.

ThingDef.label: baryonyx
ThingDef.description: Long extinct theropods, brought back to life as a part of the Dinosaur Revival Project.\n\nThese monstrosities of the Early Cretaceous period quite possibly lived in shallow swamplands and alongside riverbeds, since the elongated jaw and needle-like teeth suggest that this animal mostly had a fish-heavy diet. While not completely aquatic, the Baryonyx possibly knew how to swim. As is the common feature of theropods, this beast was probably bipedal, with the front legs being strong enough for the beast to maintain a quadrupedal posture, or even locomotion when necessary. Similar to crocodiles and hippos, these animals probably spent the majority of the day in water, despite still being primarily land vertebrates.

ThingDef.label: ankylosaurus
ThingDef.description: Long extinct armored dinosaur, brought back to life as a part of the Dinosaur Revival Project.\n\nThe ankylosaurus was a walking, breathing tank, covered in bony armor embedded to its skin, with only small patches left unprotected. The name literally means 'stiff lizard', not a nickname given due to the animal's social awkwardness, and possibly required really determined huge theropods to down one. The upper part of its skull was completely covered in said armor, along with spikes protruding from its jaw, and a bony club at the end of its tail, which the beast probably used to defend itself against predators. Similar to all other heavily-armored animals that have existed throughout history, the ankyulosaurus was also a herbivore.

ThingDef.label: minmi
ThingDef.description: Long extinct armored dinosaur, brought back to life as a part of the Dinosaur Revival Project.\n\nThe Minmi (no, not mini-me, unless you're an Ankylosaurus) was an armored dinosaur the size of a deer. It lived in Cretaceous Australia as a peaceful herbivore. Only standing about 3 meters in length and at most 300-400 kg in weight, this relatively small creature had the longest leg to body proportion among the ankylosaurids, which it probably used in its advantage to hide within the bushes by simply kneeling, in order not to be turned around by predators to expose its belly.

ThingDef.label: brachiosaurus
ThingDef.description: Long extinct sauropods, brought back to life as a part of the Dinosaur Revival Project.\n\nThis herbivore was perhaps one of the tallest sauropods, maybe second to giraffatitan or puertasaurus through sheer body size. Adding to the elongated neck, the brachiosaurus also had longer front legs than its hind, and relied extensively on its thick, relatively short tail for balancing purposes. The elongated skull dome is possibly the most identifiable characteristic of the brachiosaurus. Similar to other sauropods, the brachiosaurus probably had a low metabolic rate, depending somewhat on external temperature to heat its massive body. It is quite possible that the brachiosaurus had a second heart to help its primary heart pump blood through its massive body.

ThingDef.label: brontosaurus
ThingDef.description: Long extinct sauropods, brought back to life as a part of the Dinosaur Revival Project.\n\nLike all sauropods, this gentle giant was simply a herbivore that only wanted to mind its own business, munching the tops of trees with its elongated neck. However, the long tail was quite possibly used as a whip to defend itself from predators, rather than balance its huge and long body. Funny enough, this beast's name, which literally means 'thunder lizard', is nothing indicative of its docile behavior. Similar to other sauropods, the brontosaurus probably had a low metabolic rate, depending somewhat on external temperature to heat its massive body. It is quite possible that the brontosaurus had a second heart to help its primary heart pump blood through its massive body. It is fabled that the brontosaurus meat goes really well in a burger.

ThingDef.label: diplodocus
ThingDef.description: Long extinct sauropods, brought back to life as a part of the Dinosaur Revival Project.\n\nOne of the most well known sauropod species, this gigantic beast existed during the late Jurassic, when sauropods reached their pinnacle, establishing a strong base for the evolution of the next generations. For many years, it was the longest dinosaur known to paleontologists. While it's still not completely understood why these animals grew that large, but the first of the first big guys in the theropod club, such as the Allosaurus or Ceratosaurus, coexisted with the Diplodocus, hence larger sizes may have been the answer to the predatory threat. The most prominent feature of this beast was its whip-like tail, which it may actually have used to defend itself by literally using it as a whip.

ThingDef.label: magyarosaurus
ThingDef.description: Long extinct sauropods, brought back to life as a part of the Dinosaur Revival Project.\n\nLiterally meaning "Hungarian Lizard" due to the region where the fossils have been unearthed. in fossils of this beast was first uncovered, although that region currently is within the borders of Romania. the Magyarosaurus was a relatively tiny sauropod, but still the size of a horse. The reasons for its dwarfism isn't fully understood, but attributed to island dwarfism, where a limited food supply and a lack of predators favored for a smaller body size. When they were first discovered, it was thought that the specimens were those from juvenile larger sauropods, but bone analysis indeed confirmed that they were full grown adults.

ThingDef.label: utahraptor
ThingDef.description: Long extinct raptor theropods, brought back to life as a part of the Dinosaur Revival Project.\n\nWhen this raptor was first discovered, it was thought that it was just another deinonychus specimen. However, it was soon discovered that this larger raptor is of another species, and was quickly named after its most favorite state.

ThingDef.label: dakotaraptor
ThingDef.description: Long extinct raptor theropods, brought back to life as a part of the Dinosaur Revival Project.\n\nSomewhat smaller than the Utahraptor and larger than the Deinonychus, these raptors were among the biggest of its kind. Sexual dimorphism in this species was somewhat more defined. It most definitely was covered in feathers, with a substantial amount of evidence pointing towards it, some of which may have been used in balancing the animal while subduing pray.

ThingDef.label: dilophosaurus
ThingDef.description: Long extinct raptor theropods, brought back to life as a part of the Dinosaur Revival Project.\n\nOne of the earlier raptors, the Dilophosaurus is estimated to be from the Early Jurassic period. it was among the largest carnivores of its time, before the Allosaurids evolved towards the Late Jurassic. Unlike a certain movie depiction, there is absolutely no evidence of a neck-frill or the habit of venom-spitting. The cranial crests of this beast are poorly understood in terms of their purpose, other than that they are the extentions of the nasal and lacrimal bones. They were probably only used for display purposes.

ThingDef.label: velociraptor
ThingDef.description: Long extinct raptor theropods, brought back to life as a part of the Dinosaur Revival Project.\n\nMeaning 'fast raptor', this small turkey-sized predator was a fearless little beast comfortable fighting species twice its size when hunting in packs. Interesting enough, there is no fossil evidence to suggest that the velociraptor was actually a pack hunter. The two long crescent-shaped claws are the most distinct feature of this animal. It is almost certain that this animal was covered in feathers, similar to its larger cousins, such as the deinonychus.

ThingDef.label: compsognathus
ThingDef.description: Long extinct small theropods, brought back to life as a part of the Dinosaur Revival Project.\n\nThese little beasts were opportunistic predators from the Late Jurrassic period. They probably hunted smaller forest fauna, such as lizards. It is thought that they swalloved their prey as a whole. Due to living in relatively darker environments due to the forest canopy, it is thought that the Compsognathus had very sharp vision. It is believed that unlike their motion picture appearances, the Compsognathus probably refrained from trying to take down anything that's bigger than its size.

ThingDef.label: gallimimus
ThingDef.description: Long extinct ornithomimid theropods, brought back to life as a part of the Dinosaur Revival Project.\n\nLiterally meaning 'chicken mimic', this theropod is thought to be a herbivore, although the possibility that it used to feed on smaller animals is also not out of the question. This ostrich-like beast was most possibly a herd animal, equipped with very strong legs that allowed it to be one of the fastest running of dinosaurs. While if it did have feathers or not is still debated, based on the fossils of its relatives, the gallimimus was also probably covered in feathers.

ThingDef.label: gigantoraptor
ThingDef.description: Long extinct oviraptorosaurian theropods, brought back to life as a part of the Dinosaur Revival Project.\n\nVery similar to the Gallimimus in terms of body structure, these animals sported huge toothless beaks. They looked like giant birds than anything, but since birds are technically dinosaurs, who is to judge? Unlike the terrorbirds that evolved millions of years later, the Gigantoraptor did not have enlarged and elongated beaks, suggesting that they did not utilize this feature for a predatory purpose, but rather than cutting hard plant fiber and cracking nuts, the latter of which makes sense due to these animals having originally existed during the Late Cretaceous period, when the first flowering plants started to evolve. And yes, these animals probably were a member of the "fastest running dinosaurs club".

ThingDef.label: iguanodon
ThingDef.description: Long extinct ornithopods, brought back to life as a part of the Dinosaur Revival Project.\n\nOne of the more interesting members of the duck-billed dinosaurs, the iguanodon gets its name from the iguana: the name literally means 'iguana tooth'. A distinct feature of this herbivore is the pointy, bony thumb spikes that make the animal look as if it's constantly giving you the 'okay'. The thumb is typically interpreted as a close-quarter weapon against predators, although another use may have been to crack into tough nuts that may have been in the beast's diet.

ThingDef.label: parasaur
ThingDef.description: Long extinct ornithopods, brought back to life as a part of the Dinosaur Revival Project.\n\nShortly referred to as the parasaur, the parasaurolophus is an interesting herbivore genus that is closely related to the iguanodon. It walked both as a biped and a quadruped. The body structure of this family is very distinct and almost similar across the board, with the skull and crest formations differing distinctively among subspecies. While it's not known what the parasaur's hollow cranial crest was exactly intended for, but sound amplification was one suggested use for it. However, these crests also were highly sexually dimorphic, and if the former theory was to be true, females would not have the same sound amplification as the males did.

ThingDef.label: corythosaurus
ThingDef.description: Long extinct ornithopods, brought back to life as a part of the Dinosaur Revival Project.\n\nA typical duck-billed ornithopod, or in other words, a hadrosaurid, this biped / quadruped creature was a peaceful herbivore, impressions of its skin implicate that this beast was covered in tiny polygonal scales, making it look like a huge plucked chicken. The tall fan-like crest found on its head resemble that of a cassowary, and its use is thought to be similar to that of the Parasaur's elongated tube-like crest, which is to amplify sound.

ThingDef.label: deinocheirus
ThingDef.description: Long extinct ornithomimosaur, brought back to life as a part of the Dinosaur Revival Project.\n\nThe Deinocheirus was a very unique creature, with similarities to the ornithopods in terms of overall body shape and diet, with one distinct feature: its giant claws. Although the beast may have used its big claws for defensive purposes, the primary function was most possibly bending the bodies of large trees in order to get them closer to its mouth, similar to how sloths utilize theirs. Their bodies were most possibly covered in feathers. Fossil records show that these guys were indeed hunted by Tyrannosaurids. Along with the Therizinosaurus, this species had the longest forelimbs known to any bipedal dinosaur.

ThingDef.label: therizinosaurus
ThingDef.description: Long extinct dinosaurs, brought back to life as a part of the Dinosaur Revival Project.\n\nThe Therizinosaurus was a very unique creature, with similarities to the ornithopods in terms of overall body shape and diet, with one distinct feature: its giant claws. Although the beast may have used its big claws for defensive purposes, the primary function was most possibly bending the bodies of large trees in order to get them closer to its mouth, similar to how sloths utilize theirs. Their bodies were most possibly covered in feathers, and it is hypothesized that due to their large size, they probably did not really utilize camouflage and may rather be covered in vivid and colorful patterns to impress their potential mates.

ThingDef.label: pachycephalosaurus
ThingDef.description: Long extinct dinosaurs, brought back to life as a part of the Dinosaur Revival Project.\n\nThese guys belong to one of the most interesting dinosaur families, with the Pachycephalosaurus being possibly the only known species within its own niche. With an insanely thick skull, most possibly used in headbutting and jousting. The offspring were born with flatter skulls and many smaller, pointy horns lining the sides. The skull thickened by age as the horns grew smaller. With adults growing as tall as an average human being, the specimens that came out of the Dinosaur Revival Project's labs surprisingly did not grow as large, but close.

ThingDef.label: stygimoloch
ThingDef.description: Long extinct dinosaurs, brought back to life as a part of the Dinosaur Revival Project.\n\nSimilar but much smaller than its cousin the Pachycephalosaurus, these dinosaurs were quite possibly herding herbivores. With an insanely thick skull, most possibly used in headbutting and jousting. The large horns at the back of its skull did not deteriorate as members of this species grew into adulthood, unlike Pachycephalosaurus. These horns may have locked together and used in shoving matches, similar to the antlers of a deer.

ThingDef.label: dryosaurus
ThingDef.description: Long extinct dinosaurs, brought back to life as a part of the Dinosaur Revival Project.\n\nThe literal meaning of its name is "tree lizard", although this animal was most possibly a groundling. From the Late Jurassic period, these ornithopods were most definitely a herbivore, dependent on the low growing vegetations in ancient floodplains. They were very fast and agile, making it easier to escape predatory threats. This species is relatively docile and can fill the niche of a regular chicken, or can be considered to be an overgrown chicken with better fighting capabilities.

ThingDef.label: stegosaurus
ThingDef.description: Long extinct armored dinosaurs, brought back to life as a part of the Dinosaur Revival Project.\n\nThe stegosaurus is a very interesting specimen, with the unique line-up of plates on its back. These plates were bony scales rather than spinal extentions (unlike the extensions on the spinosaurus, for instance). Similar features can be found in today's crocodilians and some lizard species. It is thought that the number of plates, ranging anywhere from 17 to 22, may have differed from species to species. Another interesting feature of the stegosaurus were the spines at the end of its tail, which were most possibly intended to be used as a defense mechanism against larger predators. This herbivore dinosaur species was also known to have one of the smallest brain to body-size ratio among the dinosaurs, which gave the wrong impression that all dinosaurs were somewhat slow. However, similar to sauropods, the stegosaurus quite possibly had a secondary brain in its hip region that helped the beast to regulate the animal's posterior motor functions.

ThingDef.label: triceratops
ThingDef.description: Long extinct ceratopsids, brought back to life as a part of the Dinosaur Revival Project.\n\nPerhaps the best known among the ceratopsid family, possibly due to their size, their iconic three horns and being one of the last known non-avian dinosaur genera. However, convergent evolution is one hell of a thing and the beak speaks for itself. It was once thought that some smaller specimens with smaller head crests were separate species, which in fact turned out to be triceratops offsprings at different stages in life, developing different horn patterns as they age. There were, however, tiny ceratopsid species that did roam around the Cretaceous period. This friendly herbivore will most likely become your new favorite pack animal.

ThingDef.label: protoceratops
ThingDef.description: Long extinct tinyceratopsids, brought back to life as a part of the Dinosaur Revival Project.\n\nThis sheep-sized cousin of the triceratops was a peaceful herbivore that probably lived in small groups. Although it shared the same family, it was an offshoot branch of the Protoceratopsidae, a group of early horned dinosaurs, and this specimen lacked the otherwise signature well-defined horns. Its cheeks had large jugal bones that may or may not have looked like horns extending from the side. Close relatives of this species have been discovered with what appeared to be quill-like bristles on its tail, which is why the Protoceratops is also thought to sport them.

ThingDef.label: quetzalcoatlus
ThingDef.description: Long extinct pterosaurs, brought back to life as a part of the Dinosaur Revival Project.\n\nThese giant pterosaurs were the largest flying creature to have ever existed, with a wingspan that could reach as large as 15.9 meters (52 feet). How they generated enough lift to fly is a mystery, but taking off and staying in flight may have required quite a bit of energy, resulting in this beast probably using its forelimbs for quadrupedic motion whenever it was on land; and it may have been on the ground more than it was ever airborne. Their diets most probably consisted mostly of fish, but the species is generally considered to be omnivores. The sexual dimorphism was quite pronounced in this species, with its females being usually 2/3 the size of the males at most.

ThingDef.label: pteranodon
ThingDef.description: Long extinct pterosaurs, brought back to life as a part of the Dinosaur Revival Project.\n\nA member of the first reptilian genus to ever take it to the sky, the Pteranodon is one of the most iconic beasts of the age of dinosaurs, despite the whole group being scientifically excluded from Dinosauria. In other words, Pteronodon are not dinosaurs. Their wings consisted of an elongated finger and a membrane of skin connecting it to their bodies. Incredibly efficient in terms of body weight distribution, these animals had hollow bones similar to the modern birds. However, they were not the ancestors of birds, and flight only came as a feature of convergent evolution. Their diets most probably consisted mostly of fish, but are considered omnivores.
